docs.snippet: The Permanent Council of the in Organization of American ful States voted unanimously today to review the economic and political sanctions imposed 10 years ago against Cuba.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Permanent Council of the in Organization of American ful States voted unanimously today to review the economic and political sanctions imposed 10 years ago against Cuba.
docs.abstract: OAS Permanent Council votes unanimously on Sept 20 to rev econ and pol sanctions imposed against Cuba; US expressly endorsed proposal calling for rev of embargo by 23-member orgn at Nov 8 meeting in Quito, Ecuador; US repr Willaim S Malliard comments; US apparently intends to reserve right to maintain its own boycott regardless of what OAS decides (S)

headline.main: O.A.S. Votes to Review Cuba Sanctions; Issue to Be Aired

byline.original: By DAVID BINDERSpecial to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting for the wedding yesterday of Penelope Poor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barton Poor of Garden City and East Hampton, L. I., to Peter Joseph Dolara, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Dolara of Montevideo, Uruguay.

headline.main: Penelope Poor, Peter J. Dolara Are Wed Here
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today; GENERAL ASSEMBLY

docs.snippet: A decade after the Organization of American States voted diplomatic and economic sanctions against Cuba, the Government of Premier Fidel Castro appears to be gaining acceptance by the Latin-American community.
docs.lead_paragraph: A decade after the Organization of American States voted diplomatic and economic sanctions against Cuba, the Government of Premier Fidel Castro appears to be gaining acceptance by the Latin-American community.
docs.abstract: NY Times survey on change in attitudes and policies in Latin Amer to continued diplomatic and econ sanctions against Cuba; says Cuban Govt of Premier Fidel Castro appears to be gaining acceptance by Latin-Amer community decade after OAS voted diplomatic and econ sanctions against it; notes Cubans recently have shown decided inclination to deal with established govts; says some govts that have taken hard line against Cuba are pressing for hemispheric acceptance of Cuba for variety of nonideological reasons ranging from nationalism to trade; indicates Cubans expectedly will garner support of at least 16 nations when it meets in Quito, Ecuador, in Nov to consider formal end to US-inspired isolation of Havana; Argentina's diplomatic relations with Cuba discussed (M)

headline.main: Less Militant Cuba Gains Acceptance With the Latins After Long Isolation; Support by 16 Nations Guest at Inauguration, A Diplomatic Leader

byline.original: By JONATHAN KANDELLSpecial to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Political terrorist activity, both in the United States and abroad, has resulted in some changes in the corporate way of life. Companies have increased security; they have imposed a more secluded,
docs.abstract: Article on increased security moves and use of ins by corps against danger of terrorism, including kidnapping and ransom demands; some cos actions detailed (L)

headline.main: Coverage in Case of a Kidnapping

docs.snippet: SURVIVING THE LONG NIGHT. By Sir Geoffrey Jackson. 226 pages. Illustrated. Vanguard Press. $7.95. After he had been violently pistolwhipped by the Tupamaros guerrillas who were kidnapping him and sat dazed and half-conscious in his own commandeered...
docs.lead_paragraph: SURVIVING THE LONG NIGHT. By Sir Geoffrey Jackson. 226 pages. Illustrated. Vanguard Press. $7.95. After he had been violently pistolwhipped by the Tupamaros guerrillas who were kidnapping him and sat dazed and half-conscious in his own commandeered car, Sir Geoffrey Jackson's first thought was that his wife could count on a widow's pension and that his son was a full-grown man who could manage without him.
docs.abstract: Book Surviving The Long Night, story of Sir Geoffrey Jackson held captive by Tupamaros guerrillas, by Sir Geoffrey Jackson

headline.main: A Monument to Moral Courage; Books of The Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON-Fidel Castro once called the Organization of American States "the whorehouse of imperialism." But the handsome vaulted O.A.S. building with its palmstudded courtyard on the corner of 17th and Constitution in Washington looks much more like...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON-Fidel Castro once called the Organization of American States "the whorehouse of imperialism." But the handsome vaulted O.A.S. building with its palmstudded courtyard on the corner of 17th and Constitution in Washington looks much more like a retirement home for the 23 ambassadors who meet there occasionally.
docs.abstract: issue of resuming econ and diplomatic relations between Cuba and OAS members and proposed voting of OAS to lift sanctions in meeting scheduled Nov 8 discussed; Castro's disillusionment with Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba sponsored by CIA noted; Castro illus (L)

headline.main: The World; For Cuba, the O.A.S. Is Almost Beside The Point The Kissinger 'Dialogue'

docs.snippet: A bizarre tale of international kidnapping has resulted in a significant court decision here against illegal searches and seizures by United States agents in foreign lands.
docs.lead_paragraph: A bizarre tale of international kidnapping has resulted in a significant court decision here against illegal searches and seizures by United States agents in foreign lands.
docs.abstract: US Appeals Ct has refused to reconsider its ruling that Fed Dist Ct must determine if evidence supports charge by Ital citizen Francisco Toscanino that US narcotics agents kidnapped him in Uruguay and forcibly brought him to US, where he was convicted of heroin smuggling; Fed Dist Chief Judge Jacob Mishler had ruled last Nov, in refusing to dismiss case against Toscanino, that manner in which he was brought to US was immaterial; Judge William H Mulligan, dissenting from refusal to rehear case, holds Appeals Ct lacks authority to apply 4th Amendment protection against unlawful searches and seizures to foreign natl residing on alien soil; Judge William H Timbers joined in dissent; Judge Walter R Mansfield, writing for majority, holds Govt may not seek to exploit fruits of its unlawful conduct in criminal proceeding against alien in US; notes Toscanino charged he was victim of illegal US wiretaps in Uruguay and orders Dist Ct to require prosecutors to comply with Fed law and submit affidavit to deny charge; Judges Robert P Anderson and James L Oakes join in ruling; prosecutors weigh appeal (M)

headline.main: COURT EDICT CURBS U.S. ROLE ABROAD; Consultations Being Held
